qas.question: What language does phonology as a word come from?
What Greek word is -logy derived from?
A distinction was drawn between language and what?
When did Lass write about phonology?
What language does speech as a word come from?
What Greek word is speech derived from?
A distinction was drawn between phonology and what?
When did Lass write about speech?

context: The word phonology comes from the <a0_0><b5_0>Greek<b5_0/><a0_0/> φωνή, phōnḗ, "voice, sound," and the suffix -logy (which is from Greek λόγος, <a1_0><b6_0>lógos<b6_0/><a1_0/>, "word, speech, subject of discussion"). Definitions of the term vary. <a2_0><b7_0>Nikolai Trubetzkoy<b7_0/><a2_0/> in Grundzüge der Phonologie (1939) defines phonology as "the study of sound pertaining to the system of language," as opposed to phonetics, which is "the study of sound pertaining to the act of <a3_0><b8_0>speech<b8_0/><a3_0/>" (the distinction between language and speech being basically Saussure's distinction between langue and parole). More recently, Lass (<a4_0><b9_0>1998<b9_0/><a4_0/>) writes that phonology refers broadly to the subdiscipline of linguistics concerned with the sounds of language, while in more narrow terms, "phonology proper is concerned with the function, behavior and organization of sounds as linguistic items." According to Clark et al. (2007), it means the systematic use of sound to encode meaning in any spoken human language, or the field of linguistics studying this use.
